intro: Cremanthodium limprichtii, commonly known as the mountain buttercup, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of southern Africa. It belongs to the family Asteraceae and is characterized by its small, yellowish-orange flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils and is adapted to cold, arid environments. Its leaves are basal, rosette-forming, and covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
